conbody.p: Yes – it's true. In the absence of a Top-40 radio station broadcasting pop songs, Teddy Roosevelt and I did drop nickels (remember those?) in a jukebox. Our local bowling alley installed a jukebox and the vendor managed to install the latest pop hits (45 RPM records). Well it did not take long for this jukebox to attract local tweens and teens eager to hang out, chatter, and dance. The bowling alley owner blamed the rock and roll music for all the noise and commotion, but I suspect that the music simply catalyzed some changes that were already taking place in us.

section.title: Architecture and skills
section.p: When I chat with teams who have recently moved to DITA, I ask them the following questions.

li.p: What were your previous two authoring environments?
Typically the identify MS Word, unstructured Framemaker, MadCap Flare, Paligo, Markdown, Confluence, or HTML.
Were the transitions from any one of these to another as challenging or disruptive as your transition to DITA?
Universally they respond, "no". Their DITA migrations were more stressful, challenging, and iterative than they had anticipated.
What made the DITA migration more stressful than moving your content between Word and Flare or between Markdown and Framemaker?

Most mentioned that DITA required a set of new skills that the team had only partially learned or practiced. More training might have helped, but basically teams had been forced to learn new concepts and skills versus re-applying familiar ones.

A few fast swimmers focused on the state of their content before the DITA migration. If the team had taken years to develop thousands of rambling, 10-30 page source files, a transition between Flare and Word would be more straight-forward than moving the content into semantic markup, managed linking, and structured (XML) topic types. Ironically – , by providing solutions to the common limitations in linear unstructured content, DITA exposed those limitations.

section.p: Rock and roll music did not coerce or force us teens around the jukebox to sing and dance; we were ready for a change and we learned the new slang and the new dance moves to be one of the "cool kids". With its modularity, information typing, and sophisticated mechanisms for content reuse, DITA serves as that anvil or workbench for deconstructing 1990s-style docs into intelligent content. The teams, in fact, that have the least agita moving their content into DITA are the ones who have invested serious time in planning the deconstruction.
